title: Friday, Feb 3, 2023
text:
We will start our exploration of R for Data science with Chapter 3, Data Visualization.
For this to work, we need volunteers to try the exercises. You donâ€™t have to succeed, but you should get far enough to get stuck in an interesting place, which we can discuss.

Post your solutions
Post your solutions (or attempts) in Posit Cloud.
You can sign up for a free posit cloud account which allows us to share R code. Create your account at Posit.cloud, and then use the signup link to access our R group project space.
If you have a question, or want to volunteer to work on a problem, use the comment section below.

title: Jamovi
text: On Sept 6, we will look at the the free tool Jamovi which provides a graphical front end for R.

title: A package for making tables
text:
Kari points us at the gt package for making tables. https://cran.r-project.org/package=gt
This is sort of like the grammer of graphics, but for tables.

title: Plans for Spring 2023
text:
The plan for 2023 is to do a self-study on the book

R for Data Science
which is available online.
Each session, volunteers will present on the exercises in the book, and we will discuss some of the ideas.
We will also check in with some other projects that people might be working on, workshopping problems they are having.
In particular, I will present some of my ongoing work with data analysis for Physics Playground.

title: Topics for Fall, 2023
text:
Ideas for future collquia

Talk about data archiving for Physics Playground (Sep 22, Russell)
Time series (Saeyan, Oct 6)

Graphics
ARIMA models
Filters & Smoothing

Networks or graphs (Shubham, Nov 3)

Displays (DiagrammeR, graphviz)
iGraph, gRain, bnlearn (Graphs view)
ggnet

Graphs and interactive graphs

ggplot
plotly
shiny
Tableau
Power BI (Kari, Oct 20)

title: About the FSU R Group
text:
The FSU R Group is open to students, faculty, staff, alumni and general friends of Florida State University. (Being a member of the R group, makes you a friend, so really open to anyone.)
We meet to learn how to better use the R programming language (https://cloud.r-project.org/) for data analysis, statistical programming and other applications. We welcome people at all levels of experience.

title: About the FSU R Group
text:
The FSU R Group is open to students, faculty, staff, alumni and general friends of Florida State University. (Being a member of the R group, makes you a friend, so really open to anyone.)
We meet to learn how to better use the R programming language (https://cloud.r-project.org/) for data analysis, statistical programming and other applications. We welcome people at all levels of experience.

title: About the FSU R Group
text:
Mailing List and Canvas Site

Canvas Site
Much of our material, including handouts and recordings of previous sessions are available through our canvas site. If you have an FSU ID, you can self-enroll though the following link:
https://fsu.instructure.com/enroll/AWFYCW
If you do not have a current FSU ID (i.e., you are not currently faculty, staff, a student or visiting scholar), then send a note to the faculty leader, Russell Almond describing what you hope to accomplish with the R group and I will look into getting you an account.


Mailing List
We also have a self-service mailing list for the R user group. You can enroll by going to https://lists.fsu.edu/mailman/listinfo/epls-r-users.
The mailing list is low volume, mostly announcements of group activities, although members are welcome to post R related questions to the list.


Posit Cloud
You can sign up for a free posit cloud account which allows us to share R code. Create your account at Posit.cloud, and then use the signup link to access our R group project space.

title: About the FSU R Group
text:
Faculty Leader
The faculty leader for the FSU R group is Russell Almond. You can read more about him at his home page. You can also see his github and R-Universe pages.
